Chapter on Shaving the Head and Dyeing the Robe, Part 2
At that time, the prince took the priceless maá¹‡i jewel from his heavenly crown and handed it to Chanda, saying:
Chanda!
I now give you this maá¹‡i jewel. Take this jewel back to my father, King Åšuddhodana. When you arrive before the king, bow down countless times.
You know my intentions. I entrust you. You must believe me. I now order you to take this jewel back to the father king and tell him to remove all sorrow and suffering.
Also, speak well for me to the father king, saying:

I am not abandoning my father's feet out of contempt for being deceived by others, nor out of a hateful mind, nor in search of wealth, nor because of meager rewards, nor wishing to be born in the heavens;
I only see that all sentient beings are on the wrong path, confused and walking on the dark and crooked road;

I wish to create light, to eliminate such birth and death, to seek the phrase of benefit for the world without sorrow, to cut off impermanence and conditioned actions, and to leave the household life.
Great compassionate father, seeing that I delight in leaving the household life like this, you should not be sorrowful.
He spoke in verse, saying:
Even if one dwells with loved ones for a long time, when the time comes, they will surely part.
Seeing this impermanence in an instant, therefore I now seek liberation.
At that time, the prince, having spoken this verse, said these words:
I now wish to leave this sorrow and suffering, and abandon my home to go forth. Therefore, I inform my father, the great king, that he need not be sorrowful.
If there are people in the world who, because of sorrow and grief, are bound by the five desires, then those people should be sorrowful.
Why is this?
In the world, there are many people who, because of seeking wealth, give birth to children and raise them;
But it is difficult in the world to find a son who repays his parents by giving them the wealth of the Dharma.
If the father king has such a thought, thinking that this is not the time for my son to go forth,
I only wish, father king,
do not think like this. For one who seeks the Dharma, there is no time or season.
Why is this?

People living in the world, their lives are not of fixed duration. Knowing this, therefore, the wise person must definitely abandon and seek a superior place of practice. This is the definitive statement of my mind.
It is like a person living in the same room as an enemy who will surely kill them. To say My life is long is not reasonable.
Channa!
You go to my father King Shuddhodana and speak these many kinds of words to make the king's mind firm.
When you get there, skillfully use these means to comfort him and do not let him think of me.
Channa!

However, I will tell you again, if you go to my father King Shuddhodana, just speak of my unfilial actions, my lack of virtue and practice, and how the prince is like this, without any sense of gratitude or affection, do not speak of my filial behavior.
Why is this?
Because having already abandoned affection, one abandons all thoughts and worries.
At that time, Channa, having heard the prince speak such words, was all over hot and distressed, tears filling his face, he joined his palms towards the prince and said these words:
Great Sage Prince!
As the prince instructs.
But the words spoken before, greatly causing sorrow to the relatives and the father king, my mind is not happy, my heart is broken.
Like a great elephant king sinking in deep mud, unable to extricate itself.
Having heard these words, who would not shed tears?
He further said:

The mind of diligence, if other people hear it spoken of, they will still be greatly shocked, let alone me, Channa, who has been with the sage prince since childhood, on the same day and at the same time, together growing in love and respect, enjoying each other without end.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
Even if one were to make a heart out of iron, hearing such sworn words,
Who would not feel bitter and poisonous pain in their heart? Even more so for me, who loves and cherishes you, born on the same day.
At that time, Channa, having spoken this verse, said to the Holy Prince:
I will bring the king of horses for the Holy Prince to ride. By the spiritual powers of those devas, they forcefully sent me to deliver it, not of my own will.
How can I now stop the Holy Prince from leaving the home-life?
I am now a slave born on the same day, and this king of horses is no different, how can I leave the Holy Prince for even a moment and return to the palace alone?
There is no such possibility.
Holy Prince!
You should not let me send Kanthaka back home, and then have me deliver this sorrowful and mournful message of love and separation to the great father king, telling him such things.

But now, the Holy Son should not also turn his back on his aged father, the king, and leave home. That Dharma is not supreme, there is no other Dharma more wonderful and extraordinary than this, which can surpass filial piety and the love born from parents. He should also not abandon his milk-nursing aunt, MahÄprajÄpatÄ«.
In this way, the Holy Son would also become a person without gratitude and would not remember the time of his old upbringing.
Holy Son!
The primary wife YaÅ›odharÄ, a chaste woman with all virtues complete, should also not be abandoned and left behind.
However, if the Holy Son now abandons all the ÅšÄkya relatives, I, who was born on the same day as a slave, should also not be released.
But wherever the Holy Son's feet tread, I will always follow and cannot abandon him.
Great Holy Prince!

Therefore, I cannot bear to return to the city with a mind burning with the fire of sorrow and grief, to release the prince alone in this empty wilderness, and to return to the city myself. What words will King Åšuddhodana use to reproach me?
Moreover, if the prince does not return home and I go alone, the prince's friends, acquaintances, palace ladies, concubines, and queens will ask me what to say?
The prince also said to me,
You now take my evil words, defaming and humiliating me, and tell it to my relatives, causing my relatives to forget me and hate me.
How dare I falsely speak these defaming words?

I should not be ashamed, embarrassed, humiliated, or disgraced. If I want to speak evil words about the Holy Prince with my mind, thoughts, and tongue, even if I want to speak false words about the Holy Prince, who would believe my false words?
Holy Prince!
It is like someone who speaks various evil things and defaming words about the Moon God. It is difficult to find someone who hears such things and can believe them, right?
But the Holy Prince now always practices the mind of compassion. The Holy Prince's entrustment of these words is not good.
Since the Holy Prince practices great compassion, always comforting sentient beings with kind words, now abandoning all relatives, this is not good.
Therefore, it is good, Holy Prince!
Turn your mind back to home and receive happiness.'
At that time, the prince saw that Channa was like this, speaking words of sorrow, suffering, and distress. Having heard this, he replied to Channa, saying:
'Channa!
You should now abandon the suffering of separation and not be sorrowful.
Why is this?
All sentient beings, having birth and aging, all have separation.
Channa!
All sentient beings' attachments and deluded minds, those who nurture in the womb, are all false, there will be separation, they are not me, I am not them.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
Just as a great tree with many birds, each coming from different directions to roost together,
In the later day, flying apart, each going their own way, the separation of sentient beings is also like this.
Just as in the height of summer, great clouds arise, temporarily gathering and then dispersing again,
The principle of sentient beings' separation is all like this, momentarily gathering and then separating again.
Having followed each other to be born in this place, now each returns to their original place,
Do not say that I am different from you, and further create the notion of separation and dwelling.
All comings and goings are without support, but only follow the beings who have attachment,
And forcefully make distinctions between self and others.
Each has a different form and appearance, this condition is originally undefiled,
How much more so for impermanent sentient beings.
According to their ripeness, they fall away, the length of a person's life is also like this,
Long life or short life, death is certain.
Always speaking of impermanence like this, even if one's lifespan is eight great eons,
When it comes to impermanence and destruction, one will surely die, there is no doubt.
Just like people from various places each come, and together wish to drink water when they reach the river,
Or they board a boat to cross to the other shore, and once they reach the shore, they separate again.
Parents giving birth to children is also like this, as well as relatives and friends,
Although we have been together since childhood, when we grow up we will be separated from each other in an instant.
Although we may have the same family due to karmic results, the retribution of suffering and joy is not the same.
When impermanence suddenly arrives, each will abandon the other without any closeness.
At that time, after the prince spoke these verses, he said to Channa:
Good Channa!
Therefore, you should not distress your own mind now, but definitely return.
Why is it so?
If you now stay because you are attached to the great family and cannot let go, if you return home and still want to find me,
if you return to the city of Kapila and see my relatives who are worried about me, you should tell them like this:
You relatives!
You should let go of your attachment to the prince.
Why is it so?
I now know that he has a vow.
At that time, the prince then spoke this verse, entrusting Chanda, saying:ğŸ”½If now my body's blood and flesh,
as well as the joints, sinews, and skin,
all wear out and are exhausted, or if my life is not preserved,ğŸ”½if I do not abandon this heavy burden,
cross over all suffering and reach the original source,
without realizing liberation and sitting in the Way-place, I will never return to see you in vain.

At that time, when Chanda heard the prince speak this verse, he immediately spread out his own body on the ground, held the prince's two hands in front, and embraced the prince's two feet, saying these words:
Excellent, holy son!
Now I beg for your joy, do not make such painful and severe vows.
Great holy prince!
What power do I have, what spiritual virtue can I have, to be able to cause the holy son to return to the palace?
But if I return home alone, the prince's relatives will surely beat me, or perhaps the prince's father King Åšuddhodana and his aunt MahÄprajÄpatÄ« will ask me:
Where did you throw my son with the wonderful Brahma voice and great wisdom?
Then the prince said to Chanda:
Chanda!ğŸ”½Do not say such things!
Do not say such things!
My parents and relatives will not beat you if they see you returning alone from here.
Why is that?
All my relatives love you.
Chanda!
Rise quickly, rise quickly!
What has been discussed here is such a matter. If there is a person in the world who speaks with the spirit of love towards another, he will surely receive praise.
You must quickly return home, and when my father sees you return, he will regain his composure.
But my father, seeing that I have left home and heard of my going forth, is greatly distressed.

My father's body and all his relatives are all crying out, weeping and wailing. The people of the city, young and old, are all greatly distressed on my account. If they were to see you return, their hearts would be slightly comforted.'
At that time Channa rose from the ground, joined his palms, tears streaming like a flowing stream, raised his voice and cried out, addressing the prince:
'For this reason, I now wish to bring the holy prince back home, so as to prevent the great king's lineage from being cut off.'
At that time, after Channa had risen from the ground, the king of horses Kaá¹‡á¹­haka knelt on his front knees, stuck out his tongue to lick the prince's two feet, and tears flowed from his two eyes.
At that time Channa addressed the prince, saying:
'Great Sage Prince!
Although this horse is still an animal's body, it is still compassionate and sheds tears, let alone the hearts of the prince's relatives, what calamities will they see?
I only pray that the prince!

Properly observe this horse king, who now sees the prince unwilling to return home, and therefore kneels with his two front knees bent, opens his mouth, sticks out his tongue, licks the prince's feet, and with a compassionate heart, tears flow from his two eyes.'

At that time, the prince used his merits, the thousand-spoked wheel-mark adorned with the ten thousand-character pattern, like a plantain, his soft inner heart, his golden right palm, his webbed fingers, to rub the horse king Kanthaka's head, and said to him:
'Kanthaka!
You have now fulfilled your duties as a horse, and have been able to bear great burdens. From now on, you, Kanthaka, return home to take care of yourself.
This is now my last time using a carriage from my home. Traveling a long distance, I rely on you today to get through for me.
Kanthaka!

You should not be sorrowful now, do not cry or grieve. What you carry me on will bring great reward. I now wish to seek supreme, perfect enlightenment. When I realize it in the future, I will distribute the nectar and give it to you.
There is a verse that says:
The prince used his right webbed finger, with the mark of a thousand-spoked wheel,
His golden-colored, soft and pure hand, to stroke the head of the horse king Kanthaka.
It was as if two people were speaking to each other, 'You, Kanthaka, born on the same day as me,
Do not cry sorrowfully or be distressed. Your work as a horse is already done.
If I am to realize the taste of nectar, what I am carrying on you,
Repaying them, it will never be in vain.
At that time Channa said to the prince:
Great Sage Prince!

Today you have attained the vast king's position. The sage son is fully endowed with all the marks and the precious jade woman, the palace adornments are all revealed, and the remaining many kinds of five desires are the most supreme and wonderful, difficult to accomplish in the human realm, and now you have attained them.
Why does the sage son abandon this wonderful happiness and love the wilderness filled with various beasts and birds?
Moreover, this place has many bandits and terrifying things. Walking alone, sitting alone, far from all pleasures, how can it delight the mind?
The prince replied:
You good Channa!
What you say is not false.
Although that is the principle, listen carefully now, I will tell you for you.ğŸ”½Channa, listen well!

The five desires of the world will eventually return to impermanence, they are not ultimate dharmas, and do not accord with peace of mind. If obtained, they are lost, quickly passing like a stream, not staying for a moment, like dew on grass, soon to dissipate;
Like an empty fist deceiving a small child;
Like the heart of a plantain tree, without any reality;ğŸ”½Like autumn clouds rising, sometimes covering and then disappearing;
Like a flash of lightning, suddenly appearing and then extinguished;
Like bubbles on water, without any constancy;
Like a mirage in the hot sun, deceiving people.
' And he spoke a verse, saying:
'The affairs of the five desires are like a butcher's block,
Like a knife's edge smeared with honey, like using another's borrowed vessel,
Like newly dead people crying, like happily dreaming,
After waking up, searching for it is still nonexistent, like a person being shaved,
Like a tree fruit that is ripe, it will soon fall to the ground,
Just like a wicked person wielding a sword, killing an enemy without any compassion,
Just like cutting off a piece of meat, one will experience great suffering,
Just like holding a large torch, if one is not careful, one's body will be burned.
The wonderful form of humans and gods, having long enjoyed happiness,
The mind has no detachment, having obtained it, one is able to seek it again,
Just like a person who is hot and thirsty, drinking salty water again,
Seeking the five desires and so forth, not being detached is also like this.
Therefore, if a wise person wishes to be free from the five desires,
Just like the head of a poisonous snake, if seeking a long life,
Staying far away is like poison, and also like a large mass of fire,
If there is a wise person, they should abandon it from afar.
All those who have birth and death, nothing is solid,
Moment by moment, not stopping for a moment, the worldly dharmas should be like this.
Life has no freedom, and is certain to go to the realm of death.
Having contemplated in this way, do not dwell in the world.'
At that time, after the prince had spoken this verse, he said to Channa:
'Channa!
The five desires have such and other kinds of many faults.
Channa!
The royal position is also like this, mixed with various sufferings and troubles.

I see such fearful signs, so I would rather stay in this wilderness, together with the flying birds, running beasts, thieves and fearful places, alone arising, alone acting, far from desires and pleasures.
I delight in this, not in what is not wished for.
Channa!
Having heard me speak like this, do not go against me in this great matter.
Channa!
Within this kind of practice of the Dharma, I will open the Dharma eye. You should rejoice, and should not obstruct me.
At that time, Channa said to the prince:
Great Sage Prince!
If the prince definitely has this intention, I dare not disobey the prince's command now, as the prince instructs, I will return home.
At that time, the prince praised Channa, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Very good, Channa!
You now follow my intention like this, obtaining great benefits, you have done well.
At that time, the prince took off all the precious necklaces on his body, and made this great vow with his mouth:
This is my last adornment of the body as a layperson, this is my last adornment of the body as a layperson.
After taking them off, he held them in his hands and handed them to Channa. After handing them to Channa, he said again:
Channa!
You take these precious necklaces and return them to my relatives.
At that time, Channa immediately took the precious necklaces and asked the prince again:
'Holy Son!
If I return home and give these necklaces to your relatives, if they ask me:
Channa!
Why is it that you have sent the prince to another country and come back alone?
Channa!
What else did Prince Siddhartha entrust to us?
If they ask me such things, how should I reply?'
The prince said again:
'Channa!
When you return home, bow your head in homage to my father King Shuddhodana and my aunt Mahaprajapati, and also ask about the well-being of all the other relatives.
Channa!
Convey my message to King Shuddhodana, saying:
I now truly know the depth of my father's kindness. However, I went against him in order to realize supreme, perfect enlightenment.
If I attain it, I will immediately return home to see the great king.
He also specially told my aunt MahÄprajÄpatÄ«, the great queen of the country:
Do not grieve too much for me. The prince will certainly attain great benefits and return with his mother to see each other joyfully.
He also said to all the palace ladies, relatives, young children, and other ÅšÄkyas:
I now wish to break through the net of ignorance and darkness and attain the light of wisdom.
Having attained the light of wisdom, I will return to Kapilavastu.

At that time, the prince asked Chanda for the sword adorned with various jewels and seven treasures. He took the sword with his right hand, drew it from its scabbard, and then with his left hand, grasped his dark blue utpala-colored hair in a topknot. With his right hand, he held a sharp sword and cut off the hair, and with his left hand, he held it up and threw it into the air.

At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, with a rare mind, gave rise to great joy and held the prince's topknot so that it did not fall to the ground, and with a heavenly marvelous robe, he received and accepted it.
At that time, the devas made offerings with the supreme heavenly offerings.
At that time, the great assembly of devas from the Pure Abodes was not far from the prince. There was a flower garland called Sumana.
The Sumana flower transformed into a barber below, holding a sharp razor, and stood not far from the prince.
The prince, upon seeing this, said,
'Hairdresser,
can you cut my hair?'
The hairdresser replied to the prince,
'I am very able to do so.'
The prince said,
'If you are able, then you may do it now.'
At that time, the transformed hairdresser then used a sharp knife to cut the prince's hair, the mark of the invisible crown, the hair in a dark blue spiral.

When cutting the hair, Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra gave rise to a rare thought. He did not allow a single hair to fall to the ground, but with each heavenly robe he received it, and after receiving it, he went to the Heaven of the Thirty-three to make offerings to it.

From this point on, he caused the heavens to establish a festival in honor of the crown of the Bodhisattva's hair, making offerings to the festival of the crown of the Bodhisattva's hair. It continues to this day without interruption.

At that time, the prince himself untied all his necklaces and heavenly crowns, shaved off his hair and beard, and after the shaving was finished, he looked at his body and still saw the heavenly garments. Having seen this, he thought to himself:
'These garments are not the robes of one who has left home. For one who has left home, in the mountains and forests, who can give me the dyed robes of the Dharma?
According to the Dharma of leaving home, dwelling in the mountains and forests, one needs the Dharma robes.'

At that time, the gods of the Pure Abode, knowing that the prince had such thoughts, immediately transformed into the form of a hunter, wearing dyed robes, with a bow and arrows in hand, gradually approaching the prince, staying silently not far away.
At that time, the prince saw the hunter wearing dyed robes with a bow and arrows in hand. Having seen this, he immediately said these words:
'Good man of the mountains and fields!
Can you give me this dyed robe?
If you give it to me, I will give you a KÄÅ›ika robe. This robe is worth a hundred thousand gold coins and is also perfumed with various sandalwood fragrances.
What do you need with this coarse and worn-out robe?
Take this KÄÅ›ika robe instead.'
And he spoke a verse, saying:
'This is the robe of the liberated sage. It is not suitable to wear it if you hold a bow and arrow.
You should give it to me with a joyful mind. Do not be stingy. Let us exchange it for a heavenly robe together.'
At that time, the hunter replied to the Bodhisattva, saying:
'Excellent, good sir!
I now give it to you, truly without stinginess.'

At that time, the transformed person then gave the Bodhisattva the robe, and took the KÄÅ›ika robe from the Bodhisattva, which was worth a hundred thousand gold coins and was also perfumed with various sandalwood fragrances.

At that time, the Bodhisattva was greatly delighted. He accepted the dyed robe, deeply rejoicing in his good fortune. He immediately took off the KÄÅ›ika cloth he was wearing and gave it to the hunter.

Then the person transformed by the ÅšuddhÄvÄsa Heaven, having taken the exquisite KÄÅ›ika cloth from the Bodhisattva, immediately ascended into the sky with his spiritual powers, as if in a single thought, returning to the Brahma Heaven. In order to make offerings to that wonderful cloth, in front of the Bodhisattva, he rode through the sky with the spiritual powers of the celestial beings.
Having seen this, the Bodhisattva gave rise to great joy, a rare and superior wondrous mind. By the dyed robe and KÄá¹£Äya-colored cloth, he further doubled his sincere and utmost joyful mind.

At that time, after the Bodhisattva had shaved his head, he put on the dyed robe he had obtained. His appearance changed, and after he had properly attired himself, he uttered this great and far-reaching vow:
Only now can I be called a true renunciant.
At that time, the Bodhisattva sent Channa back, with tears streaming down his face as he saw Channa off.
After making his farewells, he was alone and unaccompanied. He put on the saffron-colored robes on his body and walked slowly towards the dwelling place of the sage Vará¹£ÄkÄra.
At that time, Channa bowed his head to the Bodhisattva's feet, circumambulated the Bodhisattva three times, and then turned back.

When Channa saw that the Bodhisattva had cut off his intentions and was unwilling to return home, and that his body was wearing saffron robes, his head had no heavenly crown, his beard and hair were all shaved off, and his body had no precious necklaces or exquisite KÄÅ›Ä« clothes, and that all of these were completely absent, as soon as he saw this from afar, he raised both hands, cried out at the top of his lungs, wept mournfully towards the heavens, threw himself to the ground, and fainted. After a long while, he regained consciousness.

Having returned, he stood on the ground and looked at the Bodhisattva's footprints. He cried out again, calling out in grievance. With both hands, he embraced the neck of Kanthaka, choked with sobs, and let out a great cry of lamentation.

After crying for a long time, he saw that the Bodhisattva's mind was unmoved and there was no hope. He took all the necklaces, clothes, and led the king of horses Kanthaka, turning back wanting to return home. This was the body returning, not the mind giving up.
On the road, sometimes he would think, sometimes he would cry out, sometimes he would faint and fall to the ground, sometimes he would stand straight and unable to move forward.
Sometimes he would longingly sit unhappily. Channa was like this, his mind filled with sorrow, manifesting many kinds of suffering. He gradually arrived at the city of Kapilavastu.

The horse Kaá¹‡á¹­haka repeatedly turned its head to look back at the Bodhisattva, neighed, followed Chandaka, and walked with tears streaming down.ğŸ”½The horse had previously had abundant energy and strength, but now, seeing that the Bodhisattva had left home to shave his head and beard, it was distressed, sorrowful, and constantly anguished, and its body became emaciated and its strength was exhausted.

Even if the horse was adorned with ornaments, because its mind was separated from the Bodhisattva, it had no spiritual power or virtue. It looked back many times, watched the Bodhisattva, made loud sounds, tears filled its face, and it walked with mournful neighs.
On the road, it did not eat water or grass. Afflicted by hunger and thirst, its steps were weak, and its spiritual power and spiritual energy were all diminished, and it could no longer walk.
The tears in its eyes were constantly not dry.
When the Bodhisattva first rode out, he traveled halfway before stopping for the night. Now, because his body was emaciated from the pain, it took him eight days to return home.
There is a verse:
The Bodhisattva first left at midnight, Channa bid farewell and led Kanthaka,
Because of the pain, he lost his majestic power, and it took him eight days to return home.
At that time, Channa took the horse Kanthaka and said goodbye to the prince, turning back and returning to the city of Kapilavastu.

When he first entered, it was like a person entering an empty house. Within and outside the city of Kapilavastu, on all four sides, whether it was a garden, a forest, a spring, a pond, a canal, or a park, because the prince had left home to practice asceticism, there was no majestic spiritual power, and it was withered and dried up.

The people of Kapilavastu, young and old, saw from afar that Chandaka was leading back the king of horses Kaá¹‡á¹­haka, but did not see the prince. Because they did not see him, they all followed behind Chandaka and Kaá¹‡á¹­haka, and as they went along, they asked Chandaka, saying:
Where is Prince SiddhÄrtha now?
At that time, Chandaka's tears filled his face, and he wept and choked with sobs, unable to speak.
Then all the people in the city, grieving and crying, followed after Chandaka and Kaá¹‡á¹­haka. As they went along, their hearts were filled with doubt, and they asked Chandaka, saying these words:
Where is the prince now?
He brought great joy to our country. Where did you leave him and come back?
At that time, Chandaka followed along and answered those people, saying:

'I truly did not dare to abandon the Holy Son, but the Holy Son abandoned his own palace, renounced worldly clothing and appearance, and sent me and the horse Kanthaka back. The Crown Prince alone left the mountains to go forth.'
At that time, all the people in the city, having heard these words, gave rise to a mind of extraordinary and rare events, and praised and supported, saying:
'This is an unprecedented Dharma.'
Each one in person said to each other:
'Prince Siddhartha, able to endure hardships.'
At that time, although all the people in the city spoke these words with their mouths, their tears flowed like running water. They each scolded themselves, saying such words:

'Alas, we should now follow him and go forth together. Going to that place, looking at the human lion who walks alone, we should now go to him and follow him, not allowing ourselves to be separated from the Holy Son for even one day and continue to live.'
Why is this so?
Because the city is now without that sage prince, it lacks majesty and power. This city, being without the prince, is desolate, now no different from a wilderness;
The place where he resides, because there is the majesty and power of the prince, the mountains, forests, and groves become villages again.
There is a verse that says:
The people in the city heard these words, and exclaimed, 'How strange this is!'
This place without the prince is like a wilderness, while that place with the prince is like a city-state.

At that time, when the horse king Kanthaka neighed, all the people in the city, each in their own homes, heard its voice. Having heard it, all the people, as well as the palace ladies in the two palaces, had this thought: 'The prince has returned to the city.'
At that time, the people and palace ladies, either opening the windows or pushing aside the curtains, with joyful hearts, gazed at the prince from afar.

At that time, the people and palace ladies only saw the king of horses and Chanda, separated from the prince, coming alone. Having seen this, each returned to close the windows and doors, retreated into their homes, and cried out in great distress.

At that time, King Åšuddhodana, because of the pain of love that afflicted his body, thought of wanting to see Prince SiddhÄrtha. He immediately entered the fasting hall, with a pure and clean mind, practiced austerities, was sorrowful and dispirited, and in his heart day and night sought to guard all the gods and spirits. He also made various expedient causes and conditions, wanting to see his son and comfort his heart.

At that time, Channa was sorrowful and sad, tears streaming like rain. He held Kanthaka and the priceless jeweled crown that had been worn by the prince, and brought them into King Shuddhodana's palace. It was like when a prince is killed in battle by an enemy, and those on his left and right bring his horse and ornaments into the king's palace. It was just like that.
